qas.question: Where does the digestions of some fats start?
What happens when there is a presence of fat in the small intestine?

answers.text: produces hormones that stimulate the release of pancreatic lipase from the pancreas and bile from the liver

qas.question: What does bile from the liver help do?

answers.text: helps in the emulsification of fats for absorption of fatty acids

qas.question: What is one molecule of fat?

context: Digestion of some fats can begin <a0_0>in the mouth<a0_0/> where lingual lipase breaks down some short chain lipids into diglycerides. However fats are mainly digested in <a1_0>the small intestine<a1_0/>. The presence of fat in the small intestine <a2_0>produces hormones that stimulate the release of pancreatic lipase from the pancreas and bile from the liver<a2_0/> which <a3_0>helps in the emulsification of fats for absorption of fatty acids<a3_0/>. Complete digestion of one molecule of fat (<a4_0>a triglyceride<a4_0/>) results a mixture of fatty acids, mono- and di-glycerides, as well as some undigested triglycerides, but no free glycerol molecules.
